Posts.Content: MSHH wrote: I'm brand new to the discussion boards and trying to think through options on a re-excision.  My lumpectomy for IDC came back with margins that included DCIS and a second surgery in needed.  My surgeon said he'd support whatever decision I made, but given the uncertainty of the DCIS, a bilateral mastectomy should be considered. Can anyone share their story when margins aren't clear?   I"m also wondering if I go the bilateral route with recontruction, how much time off work is required.  (non physical office work) Thanks for any advise! Dx 7/29/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: When Margins Aren't Clear MSHH patoo

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 08:21PM MSHH wrote: Thanks to all of you for your input!   I did have the 2nd opinion at a University hospital and they found 2 other areas in the same breast that they want to further image and possibly biopsy.  They also recommended participation in trials for chemo.  Their recommendation was more testing, possible biopsy, another lumpectomy, radiation and chemo. Not having clear margins and now hearing of 2 more areas to look at make the mastectomy a clearer choice for me.  But at the end of the day, I really wish I felt more certain and that everything was more black and white. I'm the breadwinner of the family, and the one with the insurance.  I know my health is the most important thing, but I can't get away from the fact that I need to have a clear timeline and get healthy and back to work.  I thought I had a good handle on everything and now find myself crying over anything every few hours.   How do you know what the right decision is?

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2010 05:05PM MSHH wrote: Thanks Patoo~   I'm HMO and did just get a referral to go outside of network.  I need to wait until my Oncotype test results are back before making the appointment. The surgeon said he'd definitely do another lumpectomy, but between what was done the first time and the area needed for the next, it would leave a deformed breast.   Plus the DCIS didn't show up on the mammogram.   It's great to get feedback - and have this place to come to.  (my poor family is so sick of this subject - but are such great support.  I need to give them a break once in awhile
